message_text: Paper Title: Colloquium: Quantum and classical discrete time crystals Paper Abstract: The spontaneous breaking of time translation symmetry has led to the discovery of a new phase of matter - the discrete time crystal. Discrete time crystals exhibit rigid subharmonic oscillations, which result from a combination of many-body interactions, collective synchronization, and ergodicity breaking. This Colloquium reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in the study of quantum and classical discrete time crystals. We focus on the breaking of ergodicity as the key to discrete time crystals and the delaying of ergodicity as the source of numerous phenomena that share many of the properties of discrete time crystals, including the AC Josephson effect, coupled map lattices, and Faraday waves. Theoretically, there exists a diverse array of strategies to stabilize time crystalline order in both closed and open systems, ranging from localization and prethermalization to dissipation and error correction. Experimentally, many-body quantum simulators provide a natural platform for investigating signatures of time crystalline order; recent work utilizing trapped ions, solid-state spin systems, and superconducting qubits will be reviewed. Finally, this Colloquium concludes by describing outstanding challenges in the field and a vision for new directions on both the experimental and theoretical fronts. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about the many-body problem:

## Definition

The quantum many-body problem is a general name for a vast category of physical problems pertaining to deriving the behavior of multi-particle systems using fundamental quantum-mechanical principles.

## Computational Challenges

Simulating the dynamics of more than three quantum-mechanical particles is already infeasible for many physical systems due to rapidly growing numerical expense.(no content)It ranks among the most computationally intensive fields of science. As a result, many-body physics most often relies on a set of approximation methods, such as the variational method and perturbation theory, specific to the problem at hand.

## Applications

Many-body problems play a central role in condensed matter physics. Additionally, N-body simulations are widely used tools in astrophysics, from investigating the dynamics of few-body systems like the Earth-Moon-Sun system to understanding the evolution of the large-scale structure of the universe.

The many-body problem is distinct from related concepts like the n-body problem in classical mechanics or the three-body problem, though they share similar mathematical challenges in predicting the behavior of multiple interacting objects.

The quantum many-body problem is a general name for a vast category of physical problems pertaining to deriving the behavior of multi-particle systems using fundamental quantum-mechanical principles.

## Computational Challenges

Simulating the dynamics of more than three quantum-mechanical particles is already infeasible for many physical systems due to rapidly growing numerical expense.(no content)It ranks among the most computationally intensive fields of science. As a result, many-body physics most often relies on a set of approximation methods, such as the variational method and perturbation theory, specific to the problem at hand.

## Applications

Many-body problems play a central role in condensed matter physics. Additionally, N-body simulations are widely used tools in astrophysics, from investigating the dynamics of few-body systems like the Earth-Moon-Sun system to understanding the evolution of the large-scale structure of the universe.

The many-body problem is distinct from related concepts like the n-body problem in classical mechanics or the three-body problem, though they share similar mathematical challenges in predicting the behavior of multiple interacting objects.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Standard-Model Extension - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard-Model_Extension"},{"title":"Replica trick - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replica_trick"},{"title":"T-symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-symmetry"},{"title":"CP violation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP_violation"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Supersymmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supersymmetry_breaking"}]

## Search Results for "Symmetry Breaking Physics"

I found comprehensive information about symmetry breaking in physics. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Core Concept

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and contemporary understandings of physics.

### Types of Symmetry Breaking

There are three types of symmetry that can be broken: discrete, continuous and gauge, ordered in increasing technicality.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking:** This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** Explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

### Important Applications

**Electroweak Interaction:** It plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.

**Chiral Symmetry Breaking:** Chiral symmetry breaking is a property of quantum chromodynamics, the quantum field theory describing these interactions, and is responsible for the bulk of the mass (over 99%) of the nucleons, and thus of all common matter.

**The Higgs Mechanism:** Gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Anderson localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anderson_localization"},{"title":"Talk:Anderson localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Anderson_localization"},{"title":"Weak localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_localization"},{"title":"Anderson model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anderson_model"},{"title":"Brian Anderson (electrical engineer) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Anderson_(academic)"},{"title":"Localization-protected quantum order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localization_protected_quantum_order"},{"title":"Alain Aspect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Aspect"},{"title":"John Ballato - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Ballato"},{"title":"Ace Attorney - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace_Attorney"}]

Here are the search results for Anderson localization:

## Definition

In condensed matter physics, Anderson localization (also known as strong localization) is the absence of diffusion of waves in a disordered medium.

## Historical Background

The phenomenon is named after American physicist P. W. Anderson, who was the first to suggest that electron localization is possible in a lattice potential, provided that the degree of randomness (disorder) in the lattice is sufficiently large, as can be realized for example in a semiconductor with impurities or defects.

## Scope and Applications

Anderson localization is a general wave phenomenon that applies to the transport of electromagnetic waves, acoustic waves, quantum waves, spin waves, etc.

## Key Distinctions

This phenomenon is to be distinguished from weak localization, which is the precursor effect of Anderson localization, and from Mott localization, named after Sir Nevill Mott, where the transition from metallic to insulating behaviour is not due to disorder, but to a strong mutual Coulomb repulsion of electrons.

## Physical Mechanism

The phenomenon of Anderson localization, particularly that of weak localization, finds its origin in the wave interference between multiple-scattering paths. In the strong scattering limit, the severe interferences can completely halt the waves inside the disordered medium.

Links: [{"title":"Coupled map lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coupled_map_lattice"},{"title":"Gauge theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauge_theory"},{"title":"Map of lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Map_of_lattices"},{"title":"Lattice model (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_model_(physics)"},{"title":"Complete lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_lattice"},{"title":"Lattice QCD - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_QCD"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Lattice (group) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(group)"},{"title":"Cooper pair - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooper_pair"},{"title":"Complemented lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complemented_lattice"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about coupled map lattices:

## Overview

A coupled map lattice (CML) is a dynamical system that models the behavior of nonlinear systems (especially partial differential equations).(no content)They are predominantly used to qualitatively study the chaotic dynamics of spatially extended systems.

## How CMLs Work

The CML system evolves through discrete time by a mapping on vector sequences. These mappings are a recursive function of two competing terms: an individual non-linear reaction, and a spatial interaction (coupling) of variable intensity.

## Classification by Coupling Strength

CMLs can be classified by the strength of this coupling parameter(s). The research literature distinguishes between different regimes:

- **Weak coupling**: Much of the current published work in CMLs is based in weak coupled systems where diffeomorphisms of the state space close to identity are studied. Weak coupling with monotonic (bistable) dynamical regimes demonstrate spatial chaos phenomena and are popular in neural models.

- **Strong coupling**: Strong coupling interactions are most well known to model synchronization effects of dynamic spatial systems such as the Kuramoto model.

## Applications

Coupled map lattices being a prototype of spatially extended systems easy to simulate have represented a benchmark for the definition and introduction of many indicators of spatio-temporal chaos.

## Classification by Coupling Strength

CMLs can be classified by the strength of this coupling parameter(s). The research literature distinguishes between different regimes:

- **Weak coupling**: Much of the current published work in CMLs is based in weak coupled systems where diffeomorphisms of the state space close to identity are studied. Weak coupling with monotonic (bistable) dynamical regimes demonstrate spatial chaos phenomena and are popular in neural models.

- **Strong coupling**: Strong coupling interactions are most well known to model synchronization effects of dynamic spatial systems such as the Kuramoto model.

## Applications

Coupled map lattices being a prototype of spatially extended systems easy to simulate have represented a benchmark for the definition and introduction of many indicators of spatio-temporal chaos.

Web search results for query: "Ergodicity statistical mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_theory"},{"title":"Ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_process"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Stationary ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_ergodic_process"},{"title":"Statistical mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics"},{"title":"Talk:Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ergodicity"},{"title":"Russell Lyons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Lyons"},{"title":"Elementary Principles in Statistical Mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elementary_Principles_in_Statistical_Mechanics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about ergodicity in statistical mechanics:

## Definition and Core Concept

In mathematics, ergodicity expresses the idea that a point of a moving system will eventually visit all parts of the space in which the system moves, in a uniform and random sense, which implies that the average behavior of the system can be deduced from the trajectory of a "typical" point.

## In Statistical Mechanics

The idea of ergodicity was born in the field of thermodynamics, where it was necessary to relate the individual states of gas molecules to the temperature of a gas as a whole and its time evolution, requiring a mathematical definition of what it means for gases to mix well together so that thermodynamic equilibrium could be defined with mathematical rigor.(no content)In physics and thermodynamics, the ergodic hypothesis says that, over long periods of time, the time spent by a system in some region of the phase space of microstates with the same energy is proportional to the volume of this region, i.e., that all accessible microstates are equiprobable over a long period of time.

## Key Implication

In physics, statistics, econometrics and signal processing, a stochastic process is said to be in an ergodic regime if an observable's ensemble average equals the time average. This is a fundamental principle that allows researchers to study systems in different ways.

## Important Limitation

Formal mathematical proofs of ergodicity in statistical physics are hard to come by; most high-dimensional many-body systems are assumed to be ergodic, without mathematical proof.

Links: [{"title":"Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal"},{"title":"Talk:Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Time_crystal"},{"title":"Quartz clock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartz_clock"},{"title":"Crystal oscillator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_oscillator"},{"title":"Rose and Time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose_and_Time"},{"title":"Time Sculpture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Sculpture"},{"title":"Talk:Final Fantasy Crystal Chronicles: Echoes of Time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Final_Fantasy_Crystal_Chronicles:_Echoes_of_Time"},{"title":"Time Walker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Walker"},{"title":"Scintillator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scintillator"},{"title":"Response time compensation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Response_time_compensation"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about **time crystals**:

## Definition

A time crystal is a quantum system of particles whose lowest-energy state is one in which the particles are in repetitive motion.(no content)While an ordinary crystal is periodic (has a repeating structure) in space, a time crystal has a repeating structure in time.

## Key Characteristics

The concept of time crystals emerged in 2012 as a question of whether it is possible to break symmetry temporally. If a discrete time-translation symmetry is broken (which may be realized in periodically driven systems), then the system is referred to as a discrete time crystal.(no content)A discrete time crystal never reaches thermal equilibrium, as it is a type of non-equilibrium matter, and breaking of time symmetry can occur only in non-equilibrium systems.

## Important Properties

Time crystals do not violate the laws of thermodynamics: energy in the overall system is conserved, and while a crystal cannot spontaneously convert thermal energy into mechanical work, it may change perpetually in a fixed pattern in time for as long as the system can be maintained.(no content)They possess "motion without energy"—their apparent motion does not represent conventional kinetic energy.

## Experimental Observation

Discrete time crystals have been observed in physics laboratories as early as 2016.(no content)One example of a time crystal is a constantly rotating ring of charged ions in an otherwise lowest-energy state.

Web search results for query: "Quantum error correction"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"Talk:Quantum error correction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantum_error_correction"},{"title":"File:Quantum error correction of phase flip using three qubits.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Quantum_error_correction_of_phase_flip_using_three_qubits.svg"},{"title":"Stabilizer code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stabilizer_code"},{"title":"Threshold theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threshold_theorem"},{"title":"Parity measurement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_measurement"},{"title":"Bacon–Shor code","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacon–Shor_code"},{"title":"Cat qubit quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat_qubit_quantum_computer"},{"title":"Qudit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qudit"},{"title":"Five-qubit error correcting code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-qubit_error_correcting_code"}]

Here are the search results for "Quantum error correction":

## Overview

Quantum error correction (QEC) comprises a set of techniques used in quantum memory and quantum computing to protect quantum information from errors arising from decoherence and other sources of quantum noise.

## Key Concepts

In most QECCs, the type of error is either a bit flip, or a phase flip, or both (corresponding to the Pauli matrices).(no content)The stabilizers to be measured are carefully chosen so as not to reveal any logical information, but only information about the errors themselves—as otherwise the measurement would destroy any quantum superposition of this logical qubit with other qubits in the quantum computer.

## Threshold Theorem

The quantum threshold theorem shows that quantum computations of arbitrary length are possible. It states that errors can be corrected by recursively concatenating quantum codes—such as CSS codes—across logarithmically many levels, provided the error rate of individual quantum gates remains below a certain threshold.(no content)As of 2004, estimates suggest this threshold could be as high as 1–3%, assuming a sufficiently large number of qubits is available.

## Notable Codes

The five-qubit code is the smallest possible code capable of protecting one logical qubit against arbitrary single-qubit errors.(no content)Alexei Kitaev introduced the toric code without boundaries, which was later adapted into the surface code with boundaries, yielding a 2D planar layout that avoids non-local measurements. Surface codes are pivotal for scalable quantum error correction in 2025, enabling below-threshold logical qubits with improved fidelity in superconducting systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

The quantum threshold theorem shows that quantum computations of arbitrary length are possible. It states that errors can be corrected by recursively concatenating quantum codes—such as CSS codes—across logarithmically many levels, provided the error rate of individual quantum gates remains below a certain threshold.(no content)As of 2004, estimates suggest this threshold could be as high as 1–3%, assuming a sufficiently large number of qubits is available.

## Notable Codes

The five-qubit code is the smallest possible code capable of protecting one logical qubit against arbitrary single-qubit errors.(no content)Alexei Kitaev introduced the toric code without boundaries, which was later adapted into the surface code with boundaries, yielding a 2D planar layout that avoids non-local measurements. Links: [{"title":"Faraday wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_wave"},{"title":"Faraday effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_effect"},{"title":"Standing wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standing_wave"},{"title":"Maxwell's equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell's_equations"},{"title":"Michael Faraday - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Faraday"},{"title":"History of electromagnetic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_electromagnetic_theory"},{"title":"James Clerk Maxwell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Faraday waves:

## What are Faraday Waves?

Faraday waves, also known as Faraday ripples, named after Michael Faraday (1791–1867), are nonlinear standing waves that appear on liquids enclosed by a vibrating receptacle.(no content)When the vibration frequency exceeds a critical value, the flat hydrostatic surface becomes unstable.

## Applications

Faraday waves have several practical uses:

- **Materials Assembly**: Faraday waves are used as a liquid-based template for directed assembly of microscale materials including soft matter, rigid bodies, biological entities (e.g., individual cells, cell spheroids and cell-seeded microcarrier beads).(no content)Unlike solid-based template, this liquid-based template can be dynamically changed by tuning vibrational frequency and acceleration and generate diverse sets of symmetrical and periodic patterns.

- **Acoustic Mixing**: This effect can also be used for mixing two liquids acoustically. Faraday waves form on the interface between the two liquids, which increases the surface area between the two, rapidly and thoroughly mixing the liquids.

- **Natural Phenomena**: This phenomenon is also used by alligators to call mates. They vibrate their lungs at low frequencies slightly below the surface, causing their spikes to move and induce surface waves. These surface waves are basically Faraday waves and one can observe the splashing effect characteristic of certain resonances.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Josephson effect"

Links: [{"title":"Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Pi Josephson junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi_Josephson_junction"},{"title":"Talk:Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Josephson voltage standard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_voltage_standard"},{"title":"Josephson diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_diode"},{"title":"Superconducting tunnel junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_tunnel_junction"},{"title":"Brian Josephson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Josephson"},{"title":"Macroscopic quantum phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroscopic_quantum_phenomena"},{"title":"Jacques Benveniste - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Benveniste"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Josephson effect:

## Overview

The Josephson effect is a phenomenon that occurs when two superconductors are placed in proximity, with some barrier or restriction between them.(no content)It is an example of a macroscopic quantum phenomenon, where the effects of quantum mechanics are observable at ordinary, rather than atomic, scale.

## Discovery and History

The effect is named after the British physicist Brian Josephson, who predicted in 1962 the mathematical relationships for the current and voltage across the weak link.(no content)Josephson was 22-years-old when he did the work on quantum tunnelling that earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1973.

## How It Works

The Josephson effect produces a current, known as a supercurrent, that flows continuously without any voltage applied, across a device known as a Josephson junction (JJ). This consists of two or more superconductors coupled by a weak link.(no content)A supercurrent could tunnel through a thin barrier, with properties including: at a junction of two superconductors, a current will flow even if there is no drop in voltage; that when there is a voltage drop, the current should oscillate at a frequency related to the drop in voltage; and that there is a dependence on any magnetic field.

## Applications

The Josephson effect has many practical applications because it exhibits a precise relationship between different physical measures, such as voltage and frequency, facilitating highly accurate measurements. Notable applications include:

- SQUIDs, or superconducting quantum interference devices, are very sensitive magnetometers that operate via the Josephson effect
- The Josephson voltage standard implements the SI definition of the volt.

Web search results for query: "Quantum simulator"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator"},{"title":"Cirq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirq"},{"title":"Hamiltonian simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_simulation"},{"title":"IBM Quantum Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Quantum_Platform"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QuTiP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QuTiP"},{"title":"Sofie Lindskov Hansen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofie_Lindskov_Hansen"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Quantum robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about quantum simulators:

## Overview

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion.(no content)In this instance, simulators are special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why They're Needed

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

## How They Work

These simulators create clean realizations of specific systems of interest, which allows precise realizations of their properties. Precise control over and broad tunability of parameters of the system allows the influence of various parameters to be cleanly disentangled.

## Physical Implementations

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Software Tools

There are also software tools available for quantum simulation, such as QuTiP, short for the Quantum Toolbox in Python, an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Trapped ion quantum computing"

Links: [{"title":"Trapped-ion quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapped-ion_quantum_computer"},{"title":"IonQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IonQ"},{"title":"Ion trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_trap"},{"title":"Talk:Trapped ion quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Trapped_ion_quantum_computer"},{"title":"Quantum gate teleportation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_gate_teleportation"},{"title":"Isaac Chuang - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Chuang"},{"title":"Mølmer–Sørensen gate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mølmer–Sørensen_gate"},{"title":"Cirac–Zoller controlled-NOT gate","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirac–Zoller_controlled-NOT_gate"},{"title":"David J. Wineland - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Wineland"},{"title":"Penning trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penning_trap"}]

Here's what I found about trapped ion quantum computing:

## Overview

A trapped-ion quantum computer (TIQC) is one proposed approach to a large-scale quantum computer where ions (charged atomic particles) can be confined and suspended in free space using electromagnetic fields.(no content)This makes the trapped-ion quantum computer system one of the most promising architectures for a scalable, universal quantum computer.

## How It Works

Qubits are stored in stable electronic states of each ion, and quantum information can be transferred through the collective quantized motion of the ions in a shared trap (interacting through the Coulomb force).(no content)Lasers are applied to induce coupling between the qubit states (for single qubit operations) or coupling between the internal qubit states and the external motional states (for entanglement between qubits).

## Performance and Advantages

The fundamental operations of a quantum computer have been demonstrated experimentally with the currently highest accuracy in trapped-ion systems.(no content)Trapped ions could provide a number of benefits over other physical qubit types in several measures, such as accuracy, scalability, predictability, and coherence time.

## Current Progress

As of December 2023, the largest number of particles to be controllably entangled is 32 trapped ions.

## Challenges

The main challenges facing trapped-ion quantum computing are the initialization of the ion's motional states and the relatively brief lifetimes of the phonon states, and decoherence is caused when the qubits interact with the external environment undesirably.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Wineland - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Wineland"},{"title":"Penning trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penning_trap"}]

Here's what I found about trapped ion quantum computing:

## Overview

A trapped-ion quantum computer (TIQC) is one proposed approach to a large-scale quantum computer where ions (charged atomic particles) can be confined and suspended in free space using electromagnetic fields.(no content)This makes the trapped-ion quantum computer system one of the most promising architectures for a scalable, universal quantum computer.

## How It Works

Qubits are stored in stable electronic states of each ion, and quantum information can be transferred through the collective quantized motion of the ions in a shared trap (interacting through the Coulomb force).(no content)Lasers are applied to induce coupling between the qubit states (for single qubit operations) or coupling between the internal qubit states and the external motional states (for entanglement between qubits).

## Performance and Advantages

The fundamental operations of a quantum computer have been demonstrated experimentally with the currently highest accuracy in trapped-ion systems.(no content)Trapped ions could provide a number of benefits over other physical qubit types in several measures, such as accuracy, scalability, predictability, and coherence time.

## Current Progress

As of December 2023, the largest number of particles to be controllably entangled is 32 trapped ions.

## Challenges

The main challenges facing trapped-ion quantum computing are the initialization of the ion's motional states and the relatively brief lifetimes of the phonon states, and decoherence is caused when the qubits interact with the external environment undesirably.

Links: [{"title":"Spin (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_(physics)"},{"title":"Spin model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_model"},{"title":"Spin-1/2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin-1/2"},{"title":"Two-state quantum system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-state_quantum_system"},{"title":"Spin–statistics theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_statistics_theorem"},{"title":"Spinor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spinor"},{"title":"Spin network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_network"},{"title":"Spin quantum number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_quantum_number"},{"title":"Spin chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_chain"},{"title":"Spintronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spintronics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about spin systems in physics:

## Overview

A spin model is a mathematical model used in physics primarily to explain magnetism, and spin models may either be classical or quantum mechanical in nature.(no content)The study of the behavior of such "spin models" is a thriving area of research in condensed matter physics.

## Key Spin Models

The Ising model describes spins (dipoles) that have only two possible states, up and down, whereas in the Heisenberg model the spin vector is allowed to point in any direction.(no content)In certain magnets, the magnetic dipoles are only free to rotate in a 2D plane, a system which can be adequately described by the so-called xy-model.

## Applications and Importance

Electron spin plays an important role in magnetism, with applications for instance in computer memories.(no content)The manipulation of nuclear spin by radio-frequency waves (nuclear magnetic resonance) is important in chemical spectroscopy and medical imaging.

## Spin Chains

A spin chain is a type of model in statistical physics that was originally formulated to model magnetic systems, which typically consist of particles with magnetic spin located at fixed sites on a lattice.(no content)A prototypical example is the quantum Heisenberg model.

## Spin Networks

In physics, a spin network is a type of diagram which can be used to represent states and interactions between particles and fields in quantum mechanics.

Web search results for query: "Superconducting qubit"

Links: [{"title":"Superconducting quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_quantum_computing"},{"title":"Transmon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmon"},{"title":"Phase qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_qubit"},{"title":"Charge qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_qubit"},{"title":"Flux qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flux_qubit"},{"title":"Yasunobu Nakamura - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yasunobu_Nakamura"},{"title":"File:Superconducting qubits electrical diagrams.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Superconducting_qubits_electrical_diagrams.pdf"},{"title":"Circuit quantum electrodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_quantum_electrodynamics"},{"title":"Qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qubit"},{"title":"Cat qubit quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat_qubit_quantum_computer"}]

## Search Results for "Superconducting Qubit"

Based on the web search, here's comprehensive information about superconducting qubits:

### Overview

A qubit is a generalization of a bit (a system with two possible states) capable of occupying a quantum superposition of both states.(no content)Superconductors are implemented at low temperatures where they have infinite conductivity and zero resistance. Each qubit is built using semiconductor circuits with an LC circuit: a capacitor and an inductor. Superconducting capacitors and inductors are used to produce a resonant circuit that dissipates almost no energy, as heat can disrupt quantum information.

### Operating Conditions and Design

Superconducting quantum computing devices are typically designed in the radio-frequency spectrum, cooled in dilution refrigerators below 15 mK and addressed with conventional electronic instruments.(no content)Typical dimensions fall on the range of micrometers, with sub-micrometer resolution, allowing for the convenient design of a Hamiltonian system with well-established integrated circuit technology.

### Key Components

One distinguishable attribute of superconducting quantum circuits is the use of Josephson junctions.(no content)Josephson junctions are superconducting elements with a nonlinear inductance, which is important for qubit implementation. The use of this nonlinear element in the resonant superconducting circuit produces uneven spacing between the energy levels.

### Types of Superconducting Qubits

There are several major types:

1. **Transmon Qubits**: A transmon is a type of superconducting charge qubit designed to have reduced sensitivity to charge noise.

2. **Flux Qubits**: Flux qubits (also known as persistent current qubits) are micrometer sized loops of superconducting metal that is interrupted by a number of Josephson junctions.

3. **Phase Qubits**: The phase qubit is a superconducting device based on the superconductor–insulator–superconductor (SIS) Josephson junction, designed to operate as a quantum bit, or qubit.

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the discrete time crystals paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (Colloquium review)

**Key Findings:**

The paper has been classified as a **survey** since it reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in the field of discrete time crystals rather than proposing entirely new methods.

**Extracted 13 Key Triples:**

1. **Time crystal** - Main concept reviewed
2. **Symmetry breaking** - Fundamental mechanism
3. **Many-body problem** - Core physics concept
4. **Ergodicity** - Central to understanding time crystal formation
5. **Josephson effect** - Related phenomenon
6. **Coupled map lattice** - Classical analog system
7. **Faraday wave** - Another related phenomenon
8. **Anderson localization** - Stabilization strategy
9. **Quantum error correction** - Stabilization method
10. **Quantum simulator** - Experimental platform
11. **Trapped-ion quantum computer** - Experimental implementation
12. **Superconducting quantum computing** - Experimental platform
13. **Spin model** - Experimental system type

All entities were linked to their corresponding Wikipedia articles and validated successfully. The analysis captures the key theoretical concepts, experimental platforms, and related phenomena that form the foundation of the discrete time crystal research field.

Sources:
- [Time crystal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal)
- [Symmetry breaking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking)
- [Many-body problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_problem)
